title: Pet (SLASH'EM)
data:
**[Pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet")** in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") are much like pets in vanilla *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*: They fight on [your](/wiki/You "You") side, eat (or starve), bring [objects](/wiki/Object "Object") to you, and respond to [whistles](/wiki/Whistle "Whistle"). SLASH'EM provides more [domestic animals](/wiki/Domestic_animal "Domestic animal") to tame and makes such [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") more frequent in the [dungeon](/wiki/Dungeon "Dungeon") - there are also more varieties of [food](/wiki/Food "Food") to tame monsters with. The normal methods of obtaining a pet in *NetHack* (e.g., starting pets, the spell of [create familiar](/wiki/Spellbook_of_create_familiar "Spellbook of create familiar"), and feeding) are also applicable in SLASH'EM.

The basic features of pets are also generally the same: they will attack other non-tame monsters in melee and generally avoid attacking stronger monsters;[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) monsters not killed by the attack that have not moved that turn may retaliate with a 3⁄4 chance.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Pets will also seek nearby objects to either eat them if applicable or bring them to you, and if not [inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate") can be fed to increase [apport](/wiki/Apport "Apport") for a while.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3).[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Pets and items

As far as pet behavior and cursed objects, SLASH'EM is *mostly* the same as *NetHack*: pets will avoid squares with cursed objects and only enter them "reluctantly" if they block the pet's path at that moment, unless that square contains food and the pet is hungry, or else has a food item that it considers a treat.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) Pets will also never pick up cursed items even if they move onto a square with one in the above circumstances.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

A primary difference is that [demonic](/wiki/Demonic "Demonic") or [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") pets, such as the tame [ghoul](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul") that a [Necromancer](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer") starts with, will instead avoid *blessed* objects in the same way that other pets avoid cursed ones. In addition, SLASH'EM provides two other types of tame monsters: the tame [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion") dispatched to you by your god from a successful [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer") or [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice"), and the [spell beings](/wiki/Spell_being "Spell being") created by the spells of [flame sphere](/wiki/Spellbook_of_flame_sphere "Spellbook of flame sphere") and [freeze sphere](/wiki/Spellbook_of_freeze_sphere "Spellbook of freeze sphere"). To be consistent with [Eva Myers' spoiler](https://sites.google.com/view/evasroguelikegamessite/tame-monsters-in-nethack-and-slashem), this article applies the term "pet" to the exclusion of tame minions and spell beings. In the [source code](/wiki/Source_code "Source code"), pets have an attached `struct edog` (identical to that of vanilla NetHack, defined at [edog.h](/wiki/Edog.h "Edog.h")).

There exists a [port of the pet ranged patch](http://bamgames.free.fr/Slashem/index.html#petranged) (by D. Shaligram, ported by Jean-Yves Moyen) that would allow pets to also attack with ranged attacks.

## Tameness

SLASH'EM makes some changes to the [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness") system:

- Most pets do not naturally lose tameness when separated from the player. Only [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless") monsters, [werecreatures](/wiki/Werecreature "Werecreature"), [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead"), [demons](/wiki/Demon "Demon"), and [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal") lose tameness[\[11\]](#cite_note-11), at a rate of one per every 150 turns separated.

  - Unlike in vanilla, monsters becoming feral this way have no chance to become hostile, although they may still become hostile if they would have starved (see below).
  - The first point of tameness is lost at 150 turns, rather than 75 turns as in vanilla.

- For ediate pets, there is a separate check to see if the monster would have starved - if that is the case, it becomes hostile.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)
  - Ediate [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion") (such as [hell hounds](/wiki/Hell_hound "Hell hound")) do not become hostile, although they may lose tameness and become peaceful.

These changes make high-level [inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate") pets such as [Solars](/wiki/Solar "Solar") and [ki-rins](/wiki/Ki-rin "Ki-rin") considerably easier to keep tame, as they will no longer lose tameness due to [level teleport traps](/wiki/Level_teleport_trap "Level teleport trap") and [trapdoors](/wiki/Trapdoor "Trapdoor"). This is a notable buff for [pacifist](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") characters relying on a [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") from an early [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish").

## Treachery

SLASH'EM also adds the `M3_TRAITOR` flag to denote monsters that have a chance of spontaneously rebelling against the player while tame, turning them hostile as well; this has no effect on peaceful monsters. You will receive a message if a monster turns traitor, and such monsters are denoted as "traitor" when examined with a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope") or [wand of probing](/wiki/Wand_of_probing "Wand of probing").

The check for betrayal occurs with a 1⁄850 chance on every move, as well as whenever you abuse the pet.[\[13\]](#cite_note-13) This check will always fail if the pet is a spell being, is further than 3 squares away, is mindless, or if you have more hit points than the pet. If those checks pass, then there is a ![(21-tameness)(abuse+1)/66(abuse+2)](/images/math/7/e/3/7e3217f4cb471fde37f80396833e4549.png) chance that the pet will turn traitor.[\[14\]](#cite_note-14) Outside of maintaining more HP than your pets, increasing tameness and avoiding abuse is the best way to *decrease* the odds of a pet rebelling.

### Messages

- <[Foo](/wiki/Foo "Foo")> turns on you!

  A tamed monster turned traitor.

- You feel uneasy about \<foo>.

  As above, but you did not see the monster became hostile.

## Diet

As in vanilla *NetHack*, each tame monster in SLASH'EM has a varied set of foods that fall into four categories: [treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat") that can raise apport, "good" food that it will normally eat whether or not it is hungry, "acceptable" food that it will eat only *when* hungry, and all other foods that it will only consider while nearly starved. While these base mechanics are unchanged, there are more monsters that can be tamed or made peaceful with food, and certain monsters can *only* be tamed by specific treat items.

Sandwiches, tortillas, cheeses, and holy wafers are the new food items introduced in SLASH'EM - these are considered "people food" and thus "acceptable" to carnivores, while herbivores will only eat them when starving.

## Strategy

Given the preponderance of stronger monsters in SLASH'EM, it is not surprising that the best pets are almost a completely different set. In terms of sheer strength, there are three monsters which stand out: the [giant shoggoth](/wiki/Giant_shoggoth "Giant shoggoth"), the [Solar](/wiki/Solar "Solar"), and the [crystal golem](/wiki/Crystal_golem "Crystal golem").

### Solar

Probably the best choice for a pet, these are essentially stronger [Archons](/wiki/Archon "Archon"). They do immense amounts of damage, wield weapons, can heal themselves, resist almost every type of elemental damage, and are guaranteed a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection"). Also, the game will always attempt to convert a Solar's [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") into [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") or [Sunsword](/wiki/Sunsword "Sunsword"). In acquiring them as pets, lawfuls have a significant advantage, for they can receive them as [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion") from [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") and possibly [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer"). Note that a minion will not pick up items at all; in particular, this means that disarming it will leave it permanently weaponless. Note that Solars are not resistant to [level drain](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain"), and thus can be hurt by wands of draining. Fortunately, monsters will not aim for them, but may hit them when aiming for you.

### Giant shoggoth

Giant shoggoths are capable of doing somewhat more damage than Solars, and are also slightly faster. In addition, they are also resistant to stoning. Also, they are the only one of the three pets to eat anything, meaning that it is easier to keep their tameness high. Unfortunately, they are capable of treachery, meaning they can spontaneously rebel, even if their tameness is not reduced to zero. Note that they enjoy [hiding](/wiki/Hiding "Hiding"), so you may need to apply a magic whistle to keep them fighting.

### Crystal golem

Crystal golems are the slowest of the above monsters, and also only have one weapon attack. It is admittedly very strong, doing 8d12 damage, but it does make their damage somewhat more variable than the above two. However, they are guaranteed to have 300 hit points, which is more than either a Solar or a giant shoggoth starts with. Also, their bodies have innate [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") and [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"). The latter property is quite useful, as it prevents them from being turned into a weak monster by a [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap"). This is a significant advantage, although somewhat less so than in vanilla, as polymorphed monsters in SLASH'EM eventually revert to their original form.

## Good steeds

### Ki-rin

As in vanilla, the [ki-rin](/wiki/Ki-rin "Ki-rin") is a formidable [flying](/wiki/Flying "Flying"), [intelligent](/wiki/Intelligent "Intelligent") steed capable of wearing amulets and (some) armor, but since it does not eat it may be harder to keep tame (especially since non-Knights riding decreases tameness).

### Vorpal jabberwock

In contrast to the ki-rin, the [vorpal jabberwock](/wiki/Vorpal_jabberwock_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Vorpal jabberwock (SLASH'EM)") eats and so its tameness can be increased, but its speed is slower than that of the ki-rin.

Pet (SLASH'EM)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Pets in SLASH'EM are much like pets in vanilla NetHack: They fight on your side, eat (or starve), bring objects to you, and respond to whistles. SLASH'EM provides more domestic animals to tame and makes such monsters more frequent in the dungeon - there are also more varieties of food to tame monsters with. The normal methods of obtaining a pet in NetHack (e.g., starting pets, the spell of create familiar, and feeding) are also applicable in SLASH'EM.

The basic features of pets are also generally the same: they will attack other non-tame monsters in melee and generally avoid attacking stronger monsters;[1] monsters not killed by the attack that have not moved that turn may retaliate with a 3⁄4 chance.[2] Pets will also seek nearby objects to either eat them if applicable or bring them to you, and if not inediate can be fed to increase apport for a while.[3].[4][5]

As above, but you did not see the monster became hostile.

Diet

As in vanilla NetHack, each tame monster in SLASH'EM has a varied set of foods that fall into four categories: treats that can raise apport, "good" food that it will normally eat whether or not it is hungry, "acceptable" food that it will eat only when hungry, and all other foods that it will only consider while nearly starved. While these base mechanics are unchanged, there are more monsters that can be tamed or made peaceful with food, and certain monsters can only be tamed by specific treat items.

Sandwiches, tortillas, cheeses, and holy wafers are the new food items introduced in SLASH'EM - these are considered "people food" and thus "acceptable" to carnivores, while herbivores will only eat them when starving.

Strategy

Given the preponderance of stronger monsters in SLASH'EM, it is not surprising that the best pets are almost a completely different set. In terms of sheer strength, there are three monsters which stand out: the giant shoggoth, the Solar, and the crystal golem.

Solar

Probably the best choice for a pet, these are essentially stronger Archons. They do immense amounts of damage, wield weapons, can heal themselves, resist almost every type of elemental damage, and are guaranteed a shield of reflection. Also, the game will always attempt to convert a Solar's long sword into Demonbane or Sunsword. In acquiring them as pets, lawfuls have a significant advantage, for they can receive them as minions from sacrifice and possibly prayer. Note that a minion will not pick up items at all; in particular, this means that disarming it will leave it permanently weaponless. Note that Solars are not resistant to level drain, and thus can be hurt by wands of draining. Fortunately, monsters will not aim for them, but may hit them when aiming for you.

Giant shoggoth

Giant shoggoths are capable of doing somewhat more damage than Solars, and are also slightly faster. In addition, they are also resistant to stoning. Also, they are the only one of the three pets to eat anything, meaning that it is easier to keep their tameness high. Unfortunately, they are capable of treachery, meaning they can spontaneously rebel, even if their tameness is not reduced to zero. Note that they enjoy hiding, so you may need to apply a magic whistle to keep them fighting.

Crystal golem

Crystal golems are the slowest of the above monsters, and also only have one weapon attack. It is admittedly very strong, doing 8d12 damage, but it does make their damage somewhat more variable than the above two. However, they are guaranteed to have 300 hit points, which is more than either a Solar or a giant shoggoth starts with. Also, their bodies have innate reflection and magic resistance. The latter property is quite useful, as it prevents them from being turned into a weak monster by a polymorph trap. This is a significant advantage, although somewhat less so than in vanilla, as polymorphed monsters in SLASH'EM eventually revert to their original form.

Good steeds

Ki-rin

As in vanilla, the ki-rin is a formidable flying, intelligent steed capable of wearing amulets and (some) armor, but since it does not eat it may be harder to keep tame (especially since non-Knights riding decreases tameness).

Vorpal jabberwock

In contrast to the ki-rin, the vorpal jabberwock eats and so its tameness can be increased, but its speed is slower than that of the ki-rin.

rawPage: '''[[Pet]]s''' in [[SLASH'EM]] are much like pets in vanilla ''[[NetHack]]'': They fight on [[you]]r side, eat (or starve), bring [[object]]s to you, and respond to [[whistle]]s. SLASH'EM provides more [[domestic animal]]s to tame and makes such [[monster]]s more frequent in the [[dungeon]] - there are also more varieties of [[food]] to tame monsters with. The normal methods of obtaining a pet in ''NetHack'' (e.g., starting pets, the spell of {{Spell of|create familiar}}, and feeding) are also applicable in SLASH'EM. The basic features of pets are also generally the same: they will attack other non-tame monsters in melee and generally avoid attacking stronger monsters;{{refsrc|dogmove.c|859|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} monsters not killed by the attack that have not moved that turn may retaliate with a {{frac|3|4}} chance.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|891|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} Pets will also seek nearby objects to either eat them if applicable or bring them to you, and if not [[inediate]] can be fed to increase [[apport]] for a while.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|470|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}}.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|200|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}}{{refsrc|dogmove.c|346|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} ==Pets and items== As far as pet behavior and cursed objects, SLASH'EM is ''mostly'' the same as ''NetHack'': pets will avoid squares with cursed objects and only enter them "reluctantly" if they block the pet's path at that moment, unless that square contains food and the pet is hungry, or else has a food item that it considers a treat.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|72|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}}{{refsrc|dogmove.c|492|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}}{{refsrc|dogmove.c|923|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}}{{refsrc|dogmove.c|1006|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} Pets will also never pick up cursed items even if they move onto a square with one in the above circumstances.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|367|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} A primary difference is that [[demonic]] or [[undead]] pets, such as the tame [[ghoul]] that a [[Necromancer]] starts with, will instead avoid ''blessed'' objects in the same way that other pets avoid cursed ones. In addition, SLASH'EM provides two other types of tame monsters: the tame [[minion]]s dispatched to you by your god from a successful [[prayer]] or [[sacrifice]], and the [[spell being]]s created by the spells of {{Spell of|flame sphere}} and {{Spell of|freeze sphere}}. To be consistent with [https://sites.google.com/view/evasroguelikegamessite/tame-monsters-in-nethack-and-slashem Eva Myers' spoiler], this article applies the term "pet" to the exclusion of tame minions and spell beings. In the [[source code]], pets have an attached struct edog (identical to that of vanilla NetHack, defined at [[edog.h]]). There exists a [http://bamgames.free.fr/Slashem/index.html#petranged port of the pet ranged patch] (by D. Shaligram, ported by Jean-Yves Moyen) that would allow pets to also attack with ranged attacks. ==Tameness== SLASH'EM makes some changes to the [[tameness]] system: * Most pets do not naturally lose tameness when separated from the player. Only [[mindless]] monsters, [[werecreature]]s, [[undead]], [[demon]]s, and [[animal]]s lose tameness{{refsrc|dog.c|508|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}, at a rate of one per every 150 turns separated. ** Unlike in vanilla, monsters becoming feral this way have no chance to become hostile, although they may still become hostile if they would have starved (see below). ** The first point of tameness is lost at 150 turns, rather than 75 turns as in vanilla. * For ediate pets, there is a separate check to see if the monster would have starved - if that is the case, it becomes hostile.{{refsrc|dog.c|527|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} ** Ediate [[minion]]s (such as [[hell hound]]s) do not become hostile, although they may lose tameness and become peaceful. These changes make high-level [[inediate]] pets such as [[Solar]]s and [[ki-rin]]s considerably easier to keep tame, as they will no longer lose tameness due to [[level teleport trap]]s and [[trapdoor]]s. This is a notable buff for [[pacifist]] characters relying on a [[figurine]] from an early [[wish]]. ==Treachery== SLASH'EM also adds the [[M3_TRAITOR]] flag to denote monsters that have a chance of spontaneously rebelling against the player while tame, turning them hostile as well; this has no effect on peaceful monsters. You will receive a message if a monster turns traitor, and such monsters are denoted as "traitor" when examined with a [[stethoscope]] or [[wand of probing]]. The check for betrayal occurs with a {{frac|850}} chance on every move, as well as whenever you abuse the pet.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|716|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} This check will always fail if the pet is a spell being, is further than 3 squares away, is mindless, or if you have more hit points than the pet. If those checks pass, then there is a (21-tameness)(abuse+1)/66(abuse+2) chance that the pet will turn traitor.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|637|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F3}} Outside of maintaining more HP than your pets, increasing tameness and avoiding abuse is the best way to ''decrease'' the odds of a pet rebelling. ===Messages=== {{message|<[[Foo]]> turns on you!|A tamed monster turned traitor.}} {{message|You feel uneasy about .|As above, but you did not see the monster became hostile.}} ==Diet== As in vanilla ''NetHack'', each tame monster in SLASH'EM has a varied set of foods that fall into four categories: [[treat]]s that can raise apport, "good" food that it will normally eat whether or not it is hungry, "acceptable" food that it will eat only ''when'' hungry, and all other foods that it will only consider while nearly starved.
